Here is a ping pong paddle which you can use by inserting your hand. A new type of paddle to the game and it is totally legal in the game of ping pong. With this new paddle you will win every game. Also with this paddle you will perform much better. The player will have more accuracy and better acceleration within the game. Also you will be able to impress others. For this project you will need wood, wood glue, lazer printer, and 400 grit X-fine sandpaper. I used ply-wood and to make the paddle I glued 2
ply-woods together. The paddle's measurement is professional measurement and will fit any hand. You may need to adjust the handles for the paddle to your own fit. Otherwise measurement is perfect. Finally assemble everything together, put the sand paper on the paddle and wait for the paddle to dry over 48 hours. There you go, now go beat every one in ping pong.

The first step of making this paddle is to go into Adobe Illustrate. Then make a new page at 20 x 20. After that make a circular shape and then make a arc at the end of the shape. Once that is done, make a new page 10 x 11. On this page you will be making a handle for the ping pong paddle. you will be making 2. One with a hole for your thumb. Second one for your other fingers to rest upon. After doing so print all of it out on plywood. You will have to print 4 sheets of plywood for the paddle. Once done glue the 2 sheets of plywood paddles together and then the other 2. Once that is done let it dry over night and then glue on the handles. Let is dry for 1-2 days and then you will be able to use your paddle.
For larger pliers and tools
If it shows up really small just make the longest axis 6 in or 152.4 mm

title: remote extruder with flexible drive shaft
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is not printable and just a concept.
I do not have the time to construct this at the moment, so i just made a sketch in Paint ;)
The idea is to keep the heavy stepper away from the extruder, like it is done with the bowden type of extruders to have lower inertia and therfore be able to drive the axis with higher speed.
The problem with the bowden ones seems to be, that due to friction, buckling of the filament and elongation of the tube the extruder response is rather slow and there is a hysteresis.
The solution with the flexible shaft should not have this problem.
I think there will be a bit torsion of the cable. to keep the influnence of this low there should be a worm-wheel kind of gear with high reduction at the extruder.
Flexible shafts exist for the Dremel kind of tools, but i think they are maybe a bit disproportional. Better would be the ones that are used for speedos in mopeds maybe.

comments.text: I am working on a very similar idea, I to am using a worm drive to compensate for the 15 degree give in the flexible axle. Was this idea ever explored?

comments.text: I liked this idea, and while I was at the hardware store I noticed an 11" flex shaft for a drill, not a dremel.  It has absolutely no play between force applied on one end and force out the other, so seems absolutely suitable from that perspective.  Unfortunately, one end is a hex socket like for a screwdriver bit, and the other a hex shaft, with a brilliant little gouge cut out for hobbing.  But I can't figure out how I'd mount a gear on it or anything...

I've noticed there is a hysteresis there too (not a term I would have thought to apply, but certainly appropriate).  Specifically I've noticed that with the dremel spinning quickly the shaft end does not stop instantly with the dremel.

Thingiverse looks like it orients the images of your stl files based on the X,Y,Z orientation of your files.
X axis are along the lines to the right
Y axis are along the lines to the left
Z axis is straight up.
You will have to rotate your stl files accordingly. Personally, I like to have the stl files oriented the way they should print which will cause less problems for most people.

description.text: Simple 8-sided die

Create crystals from super-saturated liquids with these picks. The picks are 95 centimeters wide, to straddle the top of a wide glass or jar, and have a wide terminating end to accommodate crystal growth. There are some pre-made picks (Sugar, Salt, Borax, and Copper II Sulfate) and a blank pick that can be imported into #TinkerCAD to customize for your own compounds. For some exciting times, watch the time-lapse of salt crystals forming for a couple of hours on one of these picks.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Fine

Infill:

10%

Notes: With a MakerBotMini on “standard” settings, a typical Crystal Pick will take about 45 minutes to print.

When printed, the raft can be hard to release, but the pick tapers, so if you insert a scraper or knife between the taper and the raft, you want work the raft off from the middle by working towards the ends.

These picks were created using #OnShape to fit on the #MakerBotMini. They are 95 mm by 93 mm, making them just about right to sit on the lip of a 12 ounce glass. If you are going to use #TinkerCAD to add your own text, keep the text size down to 17mm, which is about 2/3 of an inch. This project has now been posted as a public document on OnShape, if you wish to copy and modify the models themselves, they can be accessed through this link.
NGSS

Growing crystals will help students learn about the structures of crystals, how they join into larger formation and about solutions and precipitation. Depending on the age group, the students will learn about safe lab practices, measurements, and accuracy as they perform the lab or observe the teacher preparing the solutions. To include 3D modeling and allow students some autonomy in this project, teachers can allow students to choose the compound from which they will create crystals and then create their own crystal pick using the “blank” pick STL and TinkerCAD. Objectives Upon completion of this activity, students will have developed skills in lab safety while understanding crystal structures and growth, geometric shapes, and the concepts of saturation and precipitation. Standards Breakdown NGSS:
2-ESS1-1
Investigate and make observations to construct an evidence-based account that Earth events can occur quickly or slowly. 2-PS1-4
5-PS1-1
Develop a model to describe that matter is made of particles too small to be seen. HS-PS1-5
Investigate and apply scientific principles with evidence to provide an explanation about the effects of changing the temperature or concentration of particles. HS-ESS2-1
Develop a model to illustrate how Earth's internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.

Start the lesson by discussing crystal structure and how different compounds join together in a variety of geometric shapes. These are great resources for discussing crystals and shapes at an introductory level.
-Science Kids At Home
-Ducksters
-Soft Schools Proceed by stating that you are going to make crystals from everyday compounds so that you can observe them on a larger scale. The process that you are going to use is called saturation, where you increase the capacity of water to hold a compound by heating it. As it cools, the chemical compound will precipitate back out, bonding with similar compounds. These are great resources for describing saturation and precipitation:
-Preparatory Chemistry
-Soft Schools
-Your Dictionary How To Make Crystals: To create each saturated solution, start with 12 ounces of water in your sauce pot and heat to boiling. While it is boiling, slowly add the chemical, stirring so that it dissolves. Keep adding the chemical until you can see that no more will dissolve into the solution. You will now have hit the saturation point and you can move on to the next step. Allow the solution to sit for 30 to 45 minutes to cool before transferring it to the cups. Transfer the saturated solution into the cup and insert your Crystal Pick so that it straddles the lip of the cup and the end is not touching any sides. Crystal picks suspended on 12 ounce glasses of respective saturated solutions During the cooling down period, you may also wish to “seed” your crystal picks by dipping them into the solution and then dipping them into some of the remaining undissolved chemical. Allow this to dry while the solution is cooling, then transfer the liquid to the cups and slowly insert your seeded picks into the cup, straddling the lip and not touching the sides. Crystal pick Allow your solution and pick to sit for several days to build the crystals. Some go very quickly (Borax can be done overnight) and some take longer (Sugar can go for a week or longer) and the time can also depend on how super-saturated your students made their solution. Once you are ready to pull your crystal picks, hang them to drip dry in a clean cup or paper roll, then investigate the crystal structure with magnifying glasses or microscopes. Crystal Pick with Borax crystals Magnified Borax crystal Crystal Picks with Sugar crystals Magnified Sugar Crystals For Salt, you can get bigger crystals if you repeat the process with the same pick. Because salt is so heavy and precipitates out, after a day, you can remove the pick and allow it to dry (I hang them inside of cut down paper towel rolls to drip dry). Once it’s dry, reboil the solution from the cup to create your saturated solution, adding a little more salt to replenish what has already crystalized, allow it to cool for 30 minutes, then transfer to a cup and replace the pick to sit for another night. Crystal Pick with Salt crystals Magnified Salt crystals

Heat Source
Water (or distilled water)
Sauce Pot
Stirrer
Heat resistant glass or plastic cups (at most, 3.5” in diameter)
Chemical that will be dissolved for crystal making: this website has a great selection of commonly dissolved chemicals for making crystals.
3D Printed Picks for each group:

  • To enable students to create their own picks, they will need to have their own #TinkerCAD accounts and access to computers with internet connectivity. Have them import the “Blank Crystal Pick” STL into their workspace and insert letters to describe the crystal that they are making. Limit the size of the letters to 5/8” or 17mm if you are printing on a MakerBot Replicator Mini.

  • If you are printing ahead of time, I have a few pre-made models for common picks, or you can use the “Blank Crystal Pick” STL to create your own. The picks take about 45 minutes to print, using the standard print settings in the MakerBot desktop.

• 2-ESS1-1
  • 2-PS1-4
  • 5-PS1-1
  • HS-PS1-5
  • HS-ESS2-1

This activity will take several days. Set aside about one hour of class time for demonstrating equipment safety and conducting the solution activity, then several days for the crystals to precipitate out of solution onto your crystal pick. If you wish to incorporate 3D modeling, introduce the topic and activity early enough that you can have the students design their picks and then print them prior to conducting the super-saturation activity.

Students can be assessed for following directions as they create their solution and crystals.
Vocabulary and understanding can also be assessed through quizzes, crosswords, or other activities. As a writing activity, students can also be asked to draw what their crystals look like and use geometric and science vocabulary to describe the structure and appearance of their specific crystals.

description.header: To Use TinkerCAD to Add Your Own Text
description.text: TinkerCAD is a free, online CAD system from Autodesk. It allows you to import and modify STLs with premade shapes and letters. You will need to create an account with Autodesk to use TinkerCAD. When using TinkerCAD to customize your own picks, you need to first import the Blank Crystal Pick STL file into TinkerCAD. When you log in to TinkerCAD, you can see the "Import" menu on the right. Import the Blank Crystal Pick STL and make sure that your settings show that it is in millimeters and at 100%. When the pick is imported, it will come into your workspace standing up on end. Look for the curved arrow at the right hand arm of the pick. When you hover over the arrow, you'll see a gradation of angles for rotation. Rotate the pick 90 degrees away from you to get it to lay flat. Once it is flat, you'll see that it's still floating above your work surface. The black cone in the center of your pick changes the elevation of its bottom surface. Select the cone and drag your mouse to change the elevation of the pick to zero. When your pick is laying down on the work surface, you won't see a "shadow" underneath it. To add text to your project, you can scroll through the tool bar at the righthand side of the screen, or you can select the "A" at the top right of the tool bar. To add text, you drag the text from the righthand tool bar onto the workspace. Drag the letters into place along the top of the crystal pick. You can adjust their placement later, so you don't have to be perfect with your original placement. You can adjust the letters as a group, or individually. Remember, if you are printing on a #MakerBotMini, the letters should not be taller than 17 mm. By selecting one of the corner white squares, you can adjust the height and width of the letters as a group or individually, depending on your selection. You can also move them by hovering over the letters until you see a set of crosshairs. You're also going to want to make the letters less thick. The Crystal Pick is only 3 mm thick, so select the central white square to change the depth of the letters from their default 4 mm to the same 3 mm as the Crystal Pick. Once you have added your text and are happy with its placement and size, you need to group everything together for a print. Select everything and you'll see the "Group" icon on the upper right become dark so that you can click on it. This will join everything together and it will look as it should to be printed. Once you've grouped it all and you are ready to print, select the "Design" menu at the top left and proceed for your 3D printer. The #MakerBot family of printers use STL files. Select that button to download an STL file that you can then "open" in the MakerBot Desktop for printing. Happy crystal making!

Chain link which is customizable for amount of links, type (if the chain loops back into itself, or is straight), and how close the links are to each other (leave at 5, normally). I found part of source code online (on the OpenSCAD github wiki), but I changed it enough to be significantly different.
It probably won't print without a lot of supports (it has floating sections), and plastic isn't a recommended material for chains.
It may have to be scaled up/down, but that is a simple operation on a slicing program.
Currently, each link is about 4mm diameter on the ends, and is about 24mm from one end to another (approx. 17mm the short way)
None of this is by any means accurate; however, a person 3d printing a plastic chain probably doesn't need accuracy (or strength, for that matter).
A stretch of 0, or a number of links below 8, causes links in some configurations to fuse together. If problems occur, try setting stretch to 5, and the links to a large even number.
Straight chains can have any number of links without causing problems, however, stretch levels at either extreme may cause fusing of links.
About quality: Thingiverse's server works really slow in terms of rendering. The quality of the rendered parts may not be ideal. I built in a quality selection selector that would work if thingiverse was faster, but it isn't fast enough- in my testing, a 20 link circular piece would take about an hour- overloading their server, and making it take longer for everyone else. The .scad file includes a quality selector, to run on computers that have OpenSCAD installed; however, some may not want to do this. Some high resolution models are available (10 link straight, 20 link circle), so that they can be downloaded immediately, without waiting for processing. Otherwise, the normal quality setting will be fine (most printers don't even have the detail to distinguish between different resolutions), and it will take only a few minutes. First 2 gallery photos: High Resolution (Quality setting: 30. Note that this is different then $fn if you want to download OpenSCAD and adjust it)
Second 2 gallery photos: Normal Resolution (Generated with Customizer, which chooses a decent quality setting, with good speed. See the gallery models. This is the quality you will see when you customize it. If you aren't happy with this, download a high resolution pre-made file, or use OpenSCAD for more fine adjustments.)

description.text:

Update 2/18/15 - The UNTESTED version has a radius to prevent dragging on the bottom edge... I found it hit my print bed's binder clips sometimes when doing big prints.... I'll be printing one shortly to replace the one I've trimmed down, so probably go with that one if you're going to print this.  
I'm using this on the version Rostock Max v1, but I think it would probably fit the v2 as well.
Print it.  Attach 30mm fan with screws.  PLA is ok if you only print PLA, but if you switch to ABS and leave it in place, you'll want to make it out of ABS.

As part of home improvement, I need cover plates for GFCI sockets.  Those are those sockets typically found in bathrooms, kitchens, and other areas where you want to protect people with wet hands and whatnot.
This thing is a cover plate for a Standard GFCI outlet.  The size of the opening is such that it can be the basis for other types of cover plates as well.
I don't have any multi-gang GFCI sockets in my home, so I'm not quite sure of the spacing, so I've only confirmed that it will work with a single GFCI socket, although the code is there for more.

1) Find GFCI sockets in your house you need a replacement for
2) Print one of these
3) Screw it into place
4) Rejoice! This may also work for flat rocker light switches if you have those in your house.

title: Da Vinci 1 3D Printer - Hexagon Hotend with MK8 Extruder ver.1

description.text:
Please feel free to donate through Paypal to [email protected] and I will keep the designs coming.
This allows you to replace the Da Vinci 1 hot end and extruder with a "Hexagon" hot end and "MK8" extruder. I have fully machined hardened X-axis shafts available on ebay here, http://www.ebay.com/itm/161719587675?ssPageName=STRK:MESELX:IT&_trksid=p3984.m1558.l2649 UPDATE: 4/25/15 Added a carriage stl that has through holes for bushings longer than the factory bushings. "Davinci_w_bush_thru.stl" Update: 3/10/15
Added a 15mm "Bearing Spacer"
Update: 2/13/15
I added 3 new files, 15mmx.stl, 16mmx.stl, ext cap with conn.stl.
The first two are of the carriage with 2mm shaved off the bottom for better clearance of the bed screws. The third file is of the stepper cap with a new area cut out for a stepper with a pin connector.
Update: 2/18/15
Added a carriage that uses the Da Vinci bushings instead of the linear bearings.

The new carriage design does not have a flag for the X axis end stop since my Da Vinci has mechanical end stops that stick out farther than the optical stop originally did. If you need the X end stop "flag" or "boss" on the extruder you can print one and secure it to the new carriage with acetone or whatever works for you.
The Hexagon hot end utilizes a slotted aluminum plate to secure the hot end. The Hexagon hot end kit comes with, hot end, slotted mount plate, thermistor, connectors, 40mm fan, tools, setscrews, cover for the heater.
The belt gripper is printed separately to get the best results. I glued it into place with acetone and installed three screws to squeeze the belt. it is very secure
Parts hardware list:
10ea 3mmx16mm socket head cap screws
2ea 3mmx20mm Phillips head machine screws (from the MK8 extruder)
4ea 15mmx8mm linear bearings
7ea 3.5mmx 7mm sheet metal screws
4ea 3.5mm flat washers
1ea Hexagon hot end kit
1ea MK8 Chinese extruder
2ea 1/4"x1.25" nylon machine screws
Screw holes have to be tapped to 3mm and 1/4" I used bottom taps
Various clean up has to be done on the right angles, holes etc.
The carriage is designed to be printed on the right side when looking at the fan. It is completely flat on this side and makes for a better print. It places the bearing holes up for better print results.
I printed at .25mm layer height and slow speed
There are two different carriage bearing diameters 16mm and 15mm

description.text: A hexagonal chess set created in OpenSCAD.

Fork on Github! https://github.com/ryanthejuggler/para-chess 3/27/2013: updated knight and added set-plated to print the whole set at once set-plated.stl has a 4x4 inch footprint and should print just fine on an 8x8 bed. If your axis is skipping steps and ruining the build, then lower the travel speed to around 60. Definitely use support material if you don't want the knight to come out a goopy mess. Alternatively, use OpenSCAD to remix the pieces and then print. If you want to print without support material then you can adjust the tilt of the knight's head in knight.scad. Use config.scad to control size etc. Individual pieces have more settings with which you can muck about if you wish.

comments.text: Printed out several sets for our chess club - good lines and a great print on UP! Easy to finish and took primer well to black pieces from white ABS :) Will have to post some make shots once I get a camera sorted.

A base for creating attachments for some Electrolux vacuum cleaners.  My vacuum cleaner is branded Aerus, I'm not sure which vacuums are compatible with this interface.

This is just the connector part, you'll have to add a useful attachment that suits your need.  In the 123D file I've included the attachment that I designed the connector for, and it's shown in the photos, but I didn't upload the STL for it because it's a pretty crummy design.  I made it for forcing water down my shower drain to clear out all the hair that I've been losing, and it actually worked okay but it's hard to print (you can see in the photo I had to re-build part of the edge with epoxy clay) and there are better ways of doing it.
Man, these instructions are getting negative and also contain very few instructions.  Anyway, one idea I had was to build an interface onto the connector so that you can slide on any attachment.  I didn't get around to that.
So instructions: add your desired attachment design to the bottom of the connector, print it out with supports, remove the supports, and it should just slide into the vacuum handle and lock firmly in place.  Alas, it's not airtight, maybe use some silicone rubber or Sugru for that.
Total print time was around 45 minutes for the connector only, on a Replicator 2 at default settings.

This is like the minty boost project but my own DIY version that has a custom insert for an altoids tin.

All you have to do is get an Altoids container and remove mints. I used a 9v battery and connector and a 5v regulator hooked to a toggle switch. There is a salvaged USB port with a couple of resistors on the data lines (to trick apple products) and when you flip the switch a small red indicator lets you know 5v is going to the USB port for emergency charging. I'm sure you would  not get more than one or two charges on a conventional smartphone. The toggle has a momentary spring loaded position that operates a SUPER bright white LED with a resistor in series to keep it from self destructing.
Long story short this insert gives you a spot to tuck away your electronics, a spot for the 9v and of course a section for some curiously strong mints.
I made a few of these at Christmas and they were a lot of fun.
-s

comments.text: Do you have any schematics for your mintyboost design?? Amazing idea by the way,
comments.author: t2ac32

comments.text: Its just a standard mint container. The insert I made pops in and a 9v battery goes in the middle slot. The circuit is just a regulator and a switch hooked to a usb port. And some apple products require a resistor on the data lines to trick it into thinking its an apple accessory.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/aWsT3JFgRvA
Fought with this for a few months... Finally came up with an idea to use shrink wrap to cover the helmet. Worked like a champ!

Dr-shrink.com was a great source for white shrink wrap and the scan was awesome. I need to work on my technique for wrapping it, but I am really excited about the quality. I used cornstarch to coat the blue face mask and it was very effective as well.  Printed at the lowest quality with only 1 shell in about an hour. I used raft and supports as the facemask was in the air when I merged the files. Printed on a replicator 2.

description.text:
This is a mount that can hold one of Adafruit's Pro Trinkets and an accelerometer below it. It is made to be screwed onto one of the trucks of a skateboard, removing any need to drill holes into your board. It is still in the works, so I don't recommend printing out this version thinking it is good to go.  
Update (3/21/15): I have actually printed this version out and am using it for my project. It printed fine and nothing has sheared to snapped.

Using a Makerbot with ABS at 25% fill.
Can bolt onto standard skateboard trucks and can survive being ridden.

This is an enclosure for a bench power supply utilizing an ATX power supply from a PC as its power source, based on the project here. The basic idea is you build this box, then connect a spare ATX power supply to it, and voila, you have flexible bench power connections, with the ability to switch out the power supply and without having to modify the power supply itself. Pretty snazzy. The enclosure is designed for the following parts: Binding Posts Switch USB Adapter Cigarette Lighter Socket ATX Cable although you can probably find alternates that will fit.

This printed OK on my Printrbot Simple Metal, and assembles with short self-tapping screws.  
NOTE: Make sure to print with overhang supports turned on!  My first attempt on the base failed because I had it turned off, and the hole for the ATX plug got all messed up.

comments.text: I'll be changing the switch hole to accommodate a different switch... the ones I originally intended to use can't be wired to light up correctly.

Inspired by some seasonal decor seen or reddit's r/foxes, these flat pack foxes are printed in two parts that can later be fitted together or customized with paints or markers. Six variants included:
  • The "due" models have the normally white parts of the fur recessed to create a sort of lithophane look when proper back-light is applied.
  • The "mono" models are simple 2D extrusions.
  • The "outline" models are variations of the due models that include an outline around the recessed parts for strength and contrast.
  • All flavors come in normal 3mm height and thin 2mm height. The thinner ones tend to be more translucent with most plastics.
    • Any printer can print these since their fit is designed to be fairly loose. Still, some printers may 'squish' the first layer out a bit making the joints bind up. If this happens, remove and clean the slots before trying again. Raw and unpolished SVGs are also included in zip format. Credit goes to /u/foxsicle on reddit for the source images I used to make this (also for the second image in the gallery).
This is a small Nike skateboarding keychain. Thats about it! You can stop the print and change colors half way through for a nice effect.
Will print just fine anywhere from 10% infill to 100%, I like to print most of my items around 25% I use a printrbot simple and design all of my projects on Google sketchup.

Simple and counterbalanced desktop mobile.  
Back in the early days of aviation, the Gee Bee Racer was the fastest thing in the sky. A big radial engine, tiny wings, and a short fuselage gave it speed second to none.   
It payed a price for that speed though, as its poor handling earned it a reputation as a death trap for all but the best racing pilots.  
The Gee Bee Racers can be printed independently or mounted together on balanced mobile. Once mounted, they will race in circles whenever you give it a flick.
Print two Gee Bee stls and one stand stl file. Assemble logically.

title: Palmer's Pocket Razor Blade Tube Filament Cutter Plus Box Opener And Wire Stripper Pill Splitter Slicer

description.text:
I got tired of buying tube cutters that were unable to keep an edge. Now I can buy cheap razor blades as replacements. If you have a filament 3d printer (FDM), Then this cutter ( I use daily ) is a must have. Cuts Up to 1/4 (6mm) tubing.
Cuts 1.75 or 3mm filament with a strait edged or at an angle for easy feeding. Recommended usage for feeding a new filament roll. Cut the filament at an angle for easy installs with PTFE lined extruders. This also works well at opening boxes and vacuum sealed filament rolls. See the instructions. This item makes a great gift. Just about everyone can find a use for it. Edit: Now scaled to mm and a single file.
Version 8 cut was moved from 66 to 70 degrees.
Added Grooves for pill cutting.

Adults...Slide the razor blade into the back of the upper part with pliers. Gloves are recommended. Then install the lower unit and screw.
A USA quarter will fit into the slot.
The screw is a bit undersized and self threading.
Apply 3 drops of oil on to the screw,
Then work the screw back and forth until it screws down all the way.
The notch of the screw will be horizontal and aligned with the cutter.
Make sure the screw/hinge is tight enough that it wont open in your pocket. If your printer is accurate with low strings, the oil may not be needed. Oil is generally needed if printing in PETG due to the stringy nature of the material.
Or print the screw out of an alternate material to prevent galling. Everything is scaled in inch with proper gaps for FDM printers. This item has been tested thoroughly before it was made public. The metal screw (1/2"-13x1" Flat Head) can be found here. http://www.mcmaster.com/#90275a712/=w0d5w8. Single edge razor blades. https://www.amazon.com/s/?ie=UTF8&keywords=single+edged+razor+blades I've printed many of these in PLA, ABS, AND PETG with 10%-20% infill and supports.
The example shown is Green Glow In the Dark ABS.
.2mm layer.
240 C Extruder , (hovers at 237)
90 C Platform First Layer
80 C Platform Remaining Layers
ABS Slurry on a 3/8" Borosilicate glass plate Always use pliers for blade replacement. Keep out of reach of children. Possible choking hazard. If this is ever made as an injection molded item.. Send me a case of them so I never have to buy or print one again. You may sell the 3d printed version. Enjoy. Send me a comment if you love this cutter as much as I do.

This was initially designed as a fix for the unwinding that was experienced by some of our loyal patrons while using some of our thinner 1.75mm PLA 2LB Spools (see below for more on this). 
The result however is a handy clip that is helpful in a number of spool setups.
Clips 'A' and 'B' are for the 2 variations of thinner spools, clip 'C' fits our slightly thicker spools which are replacing the thin spools. See the above photos to see which spool you have.

In attempts to slim down on shipping bulk and weight we investigated a thinner Reel for our 1.75mm PLA 2LB Spools. Initial winding tests showed that it held 2LBs just perfectly with plenty of clearance. When it came time for production however, something in the winders caused a portion of them to be overwound. This caused much chagrin for some of those who purchased them and for that we are very sorry. If you haven't already, please contact us and we'll take care of you! 
The problem was isolated to a limited number of colors in 1.75mm PLA and subsequent batches of the colors were corrected.

title: Flux Rail for Flux Pinning (Quantum Levitation) Demonstration

description.text: Meissner effect / flux pinning demonstration rail suitable for popular magnet size of 10x5x3mm. The rail includes stopper ends to prevent the levitating superconductor from escaping the magnetic rail. Once printed (it takes about 3-4 hours) all you have to do is simply insert the magnets into each hole. You may have to use a bit of force as the hole is the exact dimension of the magnet. This is to ensure stability and to prevent magnets from accidentally flying out during the experiment.

This mount will allow you to put an 80mm fan on the front of your print head to blow air on the front of the extruder and print area. Could possibly be combined with a fan shroud to direct the air flow a bit more.
Also could be tweaked to have the fan point at the extruder. I included the 123d file so that it can be easily modified.

Can be printed without supports.
The mounting holes for the side of the printer might need to be drilled out.
I was able to use the existing screws on the side of the print head for mounting.
My fan needed a 20mm m3 screw, however a shorter screw would work for other fans.

comments.author: Makamaka

comments.text:
I used a fan splitter on the normal fan header of the printrboard, and then just hooked the fan up that way.
This allows the fan to be controlled via the software just the same as the other fan.

title: Manfrotto PL200 quick release plate and adapter

description.text:
There are 2 adapters in here, one has the standard overhang of the actual plate and the other has this removed. Neither have any of the holes or screws of the actual plate and are designed to be incorporated into your thing. There is a 0.1mm prominence at the top so you can union it onto your work.  
The adapter does not have any real locking mechanism because it would depend on your work. All of my cameras are front heavy so gravity is my friend... unless I tip it upside down :)  
It should be easy enough to difference out a hole for a metal pin across the front, or develop a pin to the shape of the plate and put a hole in the front to accommodate, but again, it's there for you to integrate as you need.
I would recommend printing the plate as dense as possible and with thick walls. It will deform in a real adapter and it will need to take a lot of physics.

author: celce

description.text: I spent my last penny, so I needed to (p)improvise this thing :) No seriously, the penny is the most expensive part of this bottle opener, so I decided to reduce its cost drastically. Well, actually, I simply didn't have any US coins at my disposal and even a penny makes for a pretty bulky bottle-opener, so I decided to use what every Mendel hacker has at least a few kilograms of: M8 washers I shaved of a few flats for this design to be printable in 9 minutes on my Ultimaker at 100 mm/s (0.3 solidity). With PLA this makes for a pretty strong bottle opener. The .SCAD file just imports the original file by Nick Starno, and takes a few slices off it where it's not essential. I will do extensive testing with beer bottles :) Thanks Nick, for the "original derivative"! See the video of it being made and used, in 9 minutes! http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tywVdUyxaUE 9 minutes is the fastest I could print it without too much compromise in quality, it could be nicer if you have a little more patience. The opener does look better when you print it at around 70mm/s, and it'll take about 15 minutes.

penny_opener_mod.stl is the result, penny_opener_cut_1.stl is the source file that is adjusted through OpenSCAD.
  • Put beer in fridge, or the freezer if you print it fast... ;)
  • Start printing
  • "Insert coin"... no wait. Insert washer!
  • Open bottle
  • Cheers!

author: nicksears

description.text:
I use a Samsung NX2000 for aerial photography. In order to mount it facing down under my TBS Discovery Pro Quad, I made this holder. The camera hangs off the shock absorbers (I used spare ones from the Discovery kit) very firmly but there are two loops on either side which allow for securing it with zip ties to the top plate.   
That top plate is then mounted via zipties to the flamewheel arms of the quad. I also made a screw hole for the camera just in case my locking mechanism is not strong enough to hold the camera on a rough landing.

title: Cable chain, perfect fit and rounded edges

description.text:
UPDATE 09-05: Model updated to v1.3. Not a major update, only difference compared with v1.2 is aesthetic. New photo renders are added, all source files are now included and the usage licence is changed from CC to GPL. Enjoy using this model, please share all your suggestions and remarks! UPDATE 09-02: Thanks to the suggestions of Thorn (https://youmagine.com/designs/cable-chain#!comments), I have updated the model to v1.2. I have changed back one of the two main changes in v1.1 and added slits to the female tabs, mating the links should not be a problem anymore. Photo renders are not updated yet, still renders of v1.0. UPDATE 07-02: Thanks to the suggestions, I have update the model from v1.0 to v1.1. Photo renders are not updated yet. This cable chain is different from other cable chains on YouMagine and Thingiverse, because it uses a slightly different connection method. With this connection type, no corners stick out when the cable chain is bent and the individual links are turned with respect to each other. This cable chain is meant to be used in a 3d printer like a Prusa. Start and end connection parts are not included in the design, maybe I will add them later. Or add them yourself, I have included the Solidworks source files, feel free to redesign! Printing this thing can be hard, so be careful! In my experience, you get the best results when printing not too fast and use enough support material. Turning the object in a horizontal position can be useful. A fan to cool down the object is recommended. On my P3Steel, I used the following slicer settings to get a good result: (I used Cura 15)
0.1mm layer height, 0.9mm shell thickness, 100% infill, 50mm/s print speed, 220C hotend temperature, 100C bed temperature, 15% lined touching buildplate support, 16 lines brim adhesion.
Filament: Real Dutch ABS from Reprapworld.

comments.text: Hey Earllad. I'm glad we get email notifications because I've been busy with school and I'm not on TV a lot lately. But I have been using the heck out of my Dremel for art projects and building a larger 3D printer platform independent of my Dremel. So, I think I've got nothing but positive news for you in regards to your question.
comments.author: Earllad

comments.text:
Thanks a lot man!
I've had mine for about a year. I've also had the learning experience coming back to a huge wad of plastic forming around the extruder. I do love the Dremel3d customer service, they must have got tired of my questions about clogs, they ended up sending me an entire extruder assembly for free! So, I do have those parts. My packaging is long gone, though!
I'll print that filament stand for sure. I also found a filament guide mount.
I run a makerspace for kids here and 3rd grade and up I let design for the printer, they get a big kick out of it. We have some 3d pens from Knox as well and they are pretty awesome. For me I mostly print art replicas from the really nice 3d scans on TV and design chess sets. I've been meaning to get my things uploaded, maybe finally this weekend.
I am also trying to get all the teachers here addicted to the printer, so when it does go out we can argue for funds to get another one! We print a lot of math and reading manipulatives, teaching aids and stuff like that.
Nice talking to you! I wonder how many more of us are out there. I don't think we could ever afford the makerbot, but this seems right up our alley for the size too. I also REALLY like that it's enclosed. I've already had stuff drop off a shelf and would have ruined a print if not for the enclosure.

author: touchbook

description.text:
Ein praktischer Flaschenhalter. So rollen die Flaschen im Kühlschrank nicht mehr unkontrolliert hin und her.
  • Beherbergt bis zu 8 Euro-Flaschen
  • Filigranes aber stabiles Design
  • Materialsparend

A useful bottlerack. It prevents the bottles from rolling out of the refrigerator.
  • Stores up to 8 Euro-Bottles
  • Filigree but strong design
  • Material-saving

Folgende Materialien werden zum Bau benötigt:
  • 12 Schrauben M4x10mm
  • Klebstoff
    • Die 'Strebe gross' muss zweimal ausgedruckt werden. Bei dem Zusammenbau sollte darauf geachtet werden, sie so herum einzubauen, dass sich auf der Unterseite des Flaschenhalters eine Glatte fläche ergibt. Dazu ist eine der Bohrungen nach innen versetzt (Bohrung A), die andere ist mehr am Rand (Bohrung B). Die weiter am Rand befindliche Bohrung B muss am oberen Ende sein. Bei der 'Strebe klein' ist es egal, wie herum sie eingebaut wird. Um ein Ausbrechen der Löcher zu vermeiden sollten die Stirnflächen so wie die Innenseiten der Schraublöcher mit Klebstoff bestrichen werden. Dadurch wird die Konstruktion besonders langlebig.

For building this thing, you need the following:
  • 12 screws M4x10
  • Glue
    • The part 'Strebe gross' has to be printed two times. During assembly you have to check, that you mount it the way round so that it becomes a smooth surface on the bottom. That's why one of the holes (Bohrung A) is shifted a bit to the middle of the beam, the other one is nearby the rim (Bohrung B). This hole (Bohrung B) has to be on the upper side. It does not matter in which way you fix 'Strebe klein'. To prevent the beams from breaking you can add glue to the front side and the holes of the bars. In this way you get a particular long-living construction.

Adjust line width etc for sturdyness vs weight (weight also

I designed this because my old Quad (gfk and alu) did not survive a "doing a cardwheel on beach" as new acrobatics and I needed a project to get again into 3d printing.  
And of course "Because we can" :-)  
I could only do a short test hover in my room, too much snow atm.  But it looks/flies good and stable.

It prints quite easy and is stable enough.   
I tested different Infills for the arms, but it seems not so criticall. Maybe (eyeballing) the honeycomb fill is the best for this geometry.  
I use 8x4" props on it. Motors KD A20-26M 15A 1130KV, ESC I don't know. MultiWii on a Flyduino NanoWii. Some standoffs and m3 nuts and bolts.  
Accumulator: 3S 2200 25C Turnigy.  
Use the .blend to change it to your needs. I used many modifiers, so it should be easy to chance it.
